The story centers about the separate marriage hopes of a miser's
son and daughter. The daughter
is engaged to the steward of Harpagon, the miser. This steward
is highly ineligible for marriage,
in the father's eyes, because of his
lack of money. The son, on the
other hand, is in love with one
Mariane. She is highly ineligible
for marriage to the son for the
simple reason that the father desires to wed her himself.

A comical satire on the "wild
and wooly west", by E. P. Browne,
a noted playwright, who has had
previous Broadway success, the plot
concerns the life of one Pancho
Lopez, a bad man of old Mexico.

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1932

Congratulations!
CONGRATULATIONS, new 0. D.
K.'s and Tau Beta Pi's!
In heartily congratulating the six men
who were initiated into Omicron Delta
Kappa yesterday morning, we laud the
Hopkins chapter's noteworthy, splendid
choice of student leaders upon whom to
confer the high honor.
Without a single exception, the men
have distinguished themselves on the campus in undergraduate activities and have
won the confidence and respect of their
fellow-students. Each initiate has won
the right to membership in 0. D. K. on
the merit of his past performances. Petty
politics was totally absent, for not a
single one of the members who aided in
making the selections which we so highly
praise has ever resorted to the undesirable politics to obtain the high posts to
which he has been named.
Regarded as the highest honor which
can be accorded a junior or senior at the
Hopkins, 0. D. K. is one of the most
important bodies here and has always
been regarded as the binding link between
the student body and faculty. Principally,
the honorary fraternity is a sort of clearing house for college problems and a melting pot of collegiate opinion. Each member of 0. D. K. feels it a duty to do what
he can to suggest to the administration
improvements on the campus. Though the
Hopkins chapter has always worked
quietly, it has accomplished much in its
frequent conferences with the President,
the Dean, and faculty members.
Perhaps the best expression of the significance of the honorary group is in what
Henry D. Cotton, Class of 1922, remarked last November:
"Because of the vision of its founders,
Omicron Delta Kappa occupies today a
place by itself among honor fraternities.
No other national society recognizes campus leadership as such, regardless of the
field of activity in which such leadership
is acquired. No other society carries its
purpose to the logical conclusion and
converts itself into an active organization
for the welfare of the institution in which
it is located."
Frankly, we don't know much about
Tau Beta Pi, except that it recognizes
outstanding engineering students. Nevertheless, we sincerely congratulate the
eight men who were honored by election
to the honor society of their field of
work. We are confident that each one
merits the honor accorded him.

WE DO not say that the paper will sink out of total existence if aid is not
forthcoming at once from everyone in the University. But we do say that it cannot
go on throughout the year as it should—as an official semi-weekly. We are now
turning to the faculty members, graduate students, and undergraduates to respectfully- ask that you do your share in keeping THE NEWS-LETTER A semi-weekly by
willingly paying the full amount of the subscription for your paper, the sixteenth
issue of which you receive today.
THE NEWS-LETTER is the University paper. It is a vitally necessary campus
publication which deserves everyone's financial support. It is- produced by one of
the hardest-working groups of undergraduates in the University. It is a paper for
the faculty and graduate students, who should have an interest in undergraduate
affairs, as well as the undergraduates. It is the lone University publication which
is sanctioned by the Board of Trustees.
At the Hopkins we have no faculty and graduate student support of the paper,
and of the total of $6600 collected in student activities fees THE NEWS-LETTER gets
the paltry sum of $692. Yet the Barnstormers, an organization whose efforts we
laud, which produces one profit-making play and stages two dances annually, receives
the relatively enormous sum of $1245.60. The Hullabaloo, the yearbook, which, in
due deference to its editors, is an absurdly high expensive luxury, receives $1313.80,
to which is added in June one-half of the total amount of Senior Class dues collected.
The Debate Association receives $655, only $37 less than THE NEWS-LETTER receives.
The Y. M. C. A. gets from the Council $622.80, to which is added the $1200 or
more obtained in the annual campaign for funds and the $900 appropriated by the
University. The Band gets $370.

Spiritless
THERE seems to be an obvious decrease in interest in the annual football
game between the University of Maryland
and the Johns Hopkins University. At
the Stadium, Thanksgiving Day, the
crowd was small and spiritless, even
though the two State teams played good
football in the first half and in the ke.7
ginning of the third quarter.
Neither Maryland nor Hopkins rooters
showed any enthusiasm. True it is, that
the bands representing the two institutions contributed to the event when it paraded over the greensward before the
game and between halves, but the cheerleaders couldn't elicit from the students
in the stands any spirited cheers. It was
a drab day from all angles.
We understand that with the playing
of the grid game at the Baltimore Stadium
last week the swan song was sounded for
the appearance of the Jays and Terps
in the municipal horseshoe. The classic
is to be alternated annually between
Homewood Field and College Park.
What good will be wrought, if any, by
the unaccounted-for shift in scenery remains rather dubious. We believe that
the attendance will drop off considerably
when the game moves to College Park.
Baltimoreans will not trek to the Maryland campus to witness the tilt. Of
course we believe that the change from
the Stadium to Homewood for the local
meeting is a wise one. Our athletic field
can well accommodate the steadily decreasing crowds, which attend the JayTerp clash.
To be sure, the shift in scenery for the
future games will not help spirit along
one bit. Truthfully, we don't know where
the trouble lies. Of course, the apparent
difference in calibre of the two teams may
be one reason for the lack of spirit.

After College
WHAT?

ments. It is an utter impossibility to adhere to the budget given us. We must,
then, cut out our issues and appear irregularly once per week within the near
future. But we cannot see the justice of such an action. We are, officially, a
semi-weekly paper, with a staff built for producing a semi-weekly and with a
contract based on two issues per week. Though, if we do change to a weekly
beginning March 1, we are confident that we shall find the printers sympathetic
and understanding and willing to do what they can for us, we still feel that we
deserve financial aid from the University so that we can appear semi-weekly
throughout the year.
There are, of the 915 undergraduates, only 660 who have actually paid for
THE NEWS-LETTER. The 255 others, all of whom are probably scholarship holders,
get their copies free, due to the fact the University authorities have ruled that
scholarship holders need not pay the ten-dollar S. A. C. fee. We are asking those
students to be fair and to pay the subscription fee to THE NEWS-LETTER. We must
pay for the copies which we distribute to them. We see no reason why they should
not pay for the publication if they receive it in their postoffice boxes.

Students at M. I. T. are being assessed fifty cents each as a result of
a riot in which they participated in
last spring. The charge is to reimburse a fireman for a pair of pants
he lost in the fray and to defray the
cost of several pieces of fire apparatus.

allowed THE NEWS-LETTER by the Council. It costs $2.00 to produce each student's a student told the story of Adam.

subscription annually. The unfairness of the disproportionate amount is obvious
when it is considered that advertising has fallen more than $700.00 for 1932-33.
If everyone who receives the paper and who sees the actual gravity of this
situation broadmindedly will cooperate, THE NEWS-LETTER will obtain enough funds
to turn over to the treasurer of the Student Activities Council to enable it to appear
as it should—semi-weekly. With this amount available, the Dean will approve,
we know, an increase in the printing budget item.
We admit that in past years the staffs divided the surplus which always was
on hand. We agree that it was unfair that the business managers and editors did
not consider the future and leave some funds in the treasury of THE NEWS-LETTER

form it took in 1916, sixteen years ago, we would not make this appeal.
Last year, in the last week of March, THE NEWS-LETTER went on a weekly
basis for the remainder of the college term 1931-32. With due respect to the predecessors of the writer of this editorial, that move was totally uncalled for—the 4

The HOPKINS DINING ROOM

I

You Won't Want To Miss—

move that brought on the slashed budget for 1932-33 and a misunderstanding all
around. The statement released by the Dean showed that $564.24 was available for
remuneration and a $100 surplus, which because of some absurd ruling, cannot be 4
touched by the present staff. The paper could have continued semi-weekly throughout the year of 1931-32, the last college term before the splendid regulation by
Student Activities Council, which blocks remuneration and payment of Senior Class
dues, was placed into official effect. It was upon the receipts for last year that the
1932-33 budget was based, very unwisely.
It is the principle of the situation about which, really, we are arguing. The
paper, for no good reason at all, was turned into a weekly, in the last week of
March of last year. Confident, before we signed the printing contract, that advertising would increase or remain the same as 1931-32, we were given a set-back
when national advertising stand-bys, "sure things", dropped out. Our appropriation
from the S. A. C. was not increased. The authorities slashed our working budget 4
for 1932-33. And now we find ourselves forced to turn to publishing once per
week just as last year, only earlier.
We dislike the idea. We don't believe it's fair that it should appear that the
paper is playing an annual game of beginning as a semi-weekly and changing to
a weekly.
This is the test. Does the student body, both undergraduate and graduate, and
the faculty, really desire a University newspaper? If we get no results from this
campaign, we recommend, frankly, the abolition of THE NEWS-LETTER or an immediate step be taken to assure the paper at least $2 of every ten-dollar student
activities fee. In 1928-29 and 1929-30 it received $1.60 of every $10.00.
We can't say more. The facts are before you, true and frank facts. We leave,
this matter up to your good judgment. Will yOu help?

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1932

Congratulations!
CONGRATULATIONS, new 0. D.
K.'s and Tau Beta Pi's!
In heartily congratulating the six men
who were initiated into Omicron Delta
Kappa yesterday morning, we laud the
Hopkins chapter's noteworthy, splendid
choice of student leaders upon whom to
confer the high honor.
Without a single exception, the men
have distinguished themselves on the campus in undergraduate activities and have
won the confidence and respect of their
fellow-students. Each initiate has won
the right to membership in 0. D. K. on
the merit of his past performances. Petty
politics was totally absent, for not a
single one of the members who aided in
making the selections which we so highly
praise has ever resorted to the undesirable politics to obtain the high posts to
which he has been named.
Regarded as the highest honor which
can be accorded a junior or senior at the
Hopkins, 0. D. K. is one of the most
important bodies here and has always
been regarded as the binding link between
the student body and faculty. Principally,
the honorary fraternity is a sort of clearing house for college problems and a melting pot of collegiate opinion. Each member of 0. D. K. feels it a duty to do what
he can to suggest to the administration
improvements on the campus. Though the
Hopkins chapter has always worked
quietly, it has accomplished much in its
frequent conferences with the President,
the Dean, and faculty members.
Perhaps the best expression of the significance of the honorary group is in what
Henry D. Cotton, Class of 1922, remarked last November:
"Because of the vision of its founders,
Omicron Delta Kappa occupies today a
place by itself among honor fraternities.
No other national society recognizes campus leadership as such, regardless of the
field of activity in which such leadership
is acquired. No other society carries its
purpose to the logical conclusion and
converts itself into an active organization
for the welfare of the institution in which
it is located."
Frankly, we don't know much about
Tau Beta Pi, except that it recognizes
outstanding engineering students. Nevertheless, we sincerely congratulate the
eight men who were honored by election
to the honor society of their field of
work. We are confident that each one
merits the honor accorded him.

WE DO not say that the paper will sink out of total existence if aid is not
forthcoming at once from everyone in the University. But we do say that it cannot
go on throughout the year as it should—as an official semi-weekly. We are now
turning to the faculty members, graduate students, and undergraduates to respectfully- ask that you do your share in keeping THE NEWS-LETTER A semi-weekly by
willingly paying the full amount of the subscription for your paper, the sixteenth
issue of which you receive today.
THE NEWS-LETTER is the University paper. It is a vitally necessary campus
publication which deserves everyone's financial support. It is- produced by one of
the hardest-working groups of undergraduates in the University. It is a paper for
the faculty and graduate students, who should have an interest in undergraduate
affairs, as well as the undergraduates. It is the lone University publication which
is sanctioned by the Board of Trustees.
At the Hopkins we have no faculty and graduate student support of the paper,
and of the total of $6600 collected in student activities fees THE NEWS-LETTER gets
the paltry sum of $692. Yet the Barnstormers, an organization whose efforts we
laud, which produces one profit-making play and stages two dances annually, receives
the relatively enormous sum of $1245.60. The Hullabaloo, the yearbook, which, in
due deference to its editors, is an absurdly high expensive luxury, receives $1313.80,
to which is added in June one-half of the total amount of Senior Class dues collected.
The Debate Association receives $655, only $37 less than THE NEWS-LETTER receives.
The Y. M. C. A. gets from the Council $622.80, to which is added the $1200 or
more obtained in the annual campaign for funds and the $900 appropriated by the
University. The Band gets $370.

Spiritless
THERE seems to be an obvious decrease in interest in the annual football
game between the University of Maryland
and the Johns Hopkins University. At
the Stadium, Thanksgiving Day, the
crowd was small and spiritless, even
though the two State teams played good
football in the first half and in the ke.7
ginning of the third quarter.
Neither Maryland nor Hopkins rooters
showed any enthusiasm. True it is, that
the bands representing the two institutions contributed to the event when it paraded over the greensward before the
game and between halves, but the cheerleaders couldn't elicit from the students
in the stands any spirited cheers. It was
a drab day from all angles.
We understand that with the playing
of the grid game at the Baltimore Stadium
last week the swan song was sounded for
the appearance of the Jays and Terps
in the municipal horseshoe. The classic
is to be alternated annually between
Homewood Field and College Park.
What good will be wrought, if any, by
the unaccounted-for shift in scenery remains rather dubious. We believe that
the attendance will drop off considerably
when the game moves to College Park.
Baltimoreans will not trek to the Maryland campus to witness the tilt. Of
course we believe that the change from
the Stadium to Homewood for the local
meeting is a wise one. Our athletic field
can well accommodate the steadily decreasing crowds, which attend the JayTerp clash.
To be sure, the shift in scenery for the
future games will not help spirit along
one bit. Truthfully, we don't know where
the trouble lies. Of course, the apparent
difference in calibre of the two teams may
be one reason for the lack of spirit.

ments. It is an utter impossibility to adhere to the budget given us. We must,
then, cut out our issues and appear irregularly once per week within the near
future. But we cannot see the justice of such an action. We are, officially, a
semi-weekly paper, with a staff built for producing a semi-weekly and with a
contract based on two issues per week. Though, if we do change to a weekly
beginning March 1, we are confident that we shall find the printers sympathetic
and understanding and willing to do what they can for us, we still feel that we
deserve financial aid from the University so that we can appear semi-weekly
throughout the year.
There are, of the 915 undergraduates, only 660 who have actually paid for
THE NEWS-LETTER. The 255 others, all of whom are probably scholarship holders,
get their copies free, due to the fact the University authorities have ruled that
scholarship holders need not pay the ten-dollar S. A. C. fee. We are asking those
students to be fair and to pay the subscription fee to THE NEWS-LETTER. We must
pay for the copies which we distribute to them. We see no reason why they should
not pay for the publication if they receive it in their postoffice boxes.

form it took in 1916, sixteen years ago, we would not make this appeal.
Last year, in the last week of March, THE NEWS-LETTER went on a weekly
basis for the remainder of the college term 1931-32. With due respect to the predecessors of the writer of this editorial, that move was totally uncalled for—the 4

The HOPKINS DINING ROOM

I

You Won't Want To Miss—

move that brought on the slashed budget for 1932-33 and a misunderstanding all
around. The statement released by the Dean showed that $564.24 was available for
remuneration and a $100 surplus, which because of some absurd ruling, cannot be 4
touched by the present staff. The paper could have continued semi-weekly throughout the year of 1931-32, the last college term before the splendid regulation by
Student Activities Council, which blocks remuneration and payment of Senior Class
dues, was placed into official effect. It was upon the receipts for last year that the
1932-33 budget was based, very unwisely.
It is the principle of the situation about which, really, we are arguing. The
paper, for no good reason at all, was turned into a weekly, in the last week of
March of last year. Confident, before we signed the printing contract, that advertising would increase or remain the same as 1931-32, we were given a set-back
when national advertising stand-bys, "sure things", dropped out. Our appropriation
from the S. A. C. was not increased. The authorities slashed our working budget 4
for 1932-33. And now we find ourselves forced to turn to publishing once per
week just as last year, only earlier.
We dislike the idea. We don't believe it's fair that it should appear that the
paper is playing an annual game of beginning as a semi-weekly and changing to
a weekly.
This is the test. Does the student body, both undergraduate and graduate, and
the faculty, really desire a University newspaper? If we get no results from this
campaign, we recommend, frankly, the abolition of THE NEWS-LETTER or an immediate step be taken to assure the paper at least $2 of every ten-dollar student
activities fee. In 1928-29 and 1929-30 it received $1.60 of every $10.00.
We can't say more. The facts are before you, true and frank facts. We leave,
this matter up to your good judgment. Will yOu help?
